newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish law on money laundering goes into effect.
newsitem.headline: Turkish law on money laundering goes into effect.

text.p: A Turkish law aimed at curbing money laundering went into effect on Wednesday with the publication of a related regulation in the country's Official Gazette.
Turkey's parliament passed a money laundering law last November, but its implementation had been delayed because of political turmoil.
The regulation sets out the procedure for "researching, analysing and identifying suspicious transactions, gains made from money laundering and identitying those involved."
The international Financial Action Task Force warned Turkey in June that it must introduce such a law or else face potentially damaging action by the world's banking community.
The task force said Turkey was the only member of the 26-nation group not to have satisfied rules on money laundering regulations.

The new regulation will require financial institutions to pass on information connected with possible money laundering. This demand will go into effect on October 1, but all other regulations become effective immediately.
The identification will be required of customers carrying out transactions worth more than two billion Turkish lira ($13,400) and all information on such transactions must be kept for five years.
Any transaction worth more than five billion lira must be reported to the financial crimes research board, which has been set up to monitor implementation of the regulation.
The stipulated sums will be raised each year in line with inflation, which in Turkey is currently around an annual 75 percent.
